metadata.case_name: Landowners (Petitioners) v. State of Himachal Pradesh

facts.text: Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953 (Himachal 15 of 1954) passed by Legislative Assembly of State of Himachal Pradesh created by Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act 32 of 1954.
President of India gave assent to the Bill on November 23, 1954, making it the Abolition Act.
Abolition Act brought into force on January 26, 1955 by notification under s. 1(3).
Section 11 confers right on tenants (not sub-tenants) to acquire landowner's interest on payment of compensation.
Section 14 permits tenant to acquire portion of lands on surrender of rest.
Section 15 allows State Government to acquire landowner's rights by notification.
Section 16 provides compensation to landowners under ss.12 and 13.
Section 27: Landowners holding land with annual revenue > Rs.125, rights vest in State; compensation per Schedule II or I.
Compensation in Schedule II may be no more than twice land revenue.
Section 39 fixes maximum rent at one fourth of crop, possibly covering land revenue, rates, cesses.
Petitioners are landowners challenging constitutional validity of Abolition Act under Art.32.
Old Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur were separate Part C States under First Schedule to Constitution.
Government of Part C States Act 49 of 1951 applied to old Himachal Pradesh; Bilaspur excluded.
Old Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly had 36 seats; elections held in 1952.
Bill (Himachal 15 of 1953) introduced in first session of old Himachal Pradesh Assembly in 1953.
Parliament enacted Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act 32 of 1954 on May 8, 1954; assent May 28, 1954; force July 1, 1954.
New State Act s.3 created new Part C State 'Himachal Pradesh' uniting old HP and Bilaspur.
New State Act s.12: New Legislative Assembly with 41 seats by direct election.
New State Act s.15(1): 36 sitting members of old HP Assembly deemed elected to new Assembly.
Elections for 5 seats from Bilaspur area held May 13, 1955.
Notification dated July 7, 1954 summoned 'Second Session, 1954' of Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly from August 16, 1954.
No notification declaring 36 old members as members of new Assembly under s.74 Representation of People Act.
36 old members did not make fresh oath or affirmation as required by s.14 Part C States Act.
No election of Speaker for new Assembly.
Session summoned described as 'second session' despite being first for new State.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Abolition Act is void for not having been passed by a duly constituted legislature.
Whether provisions of Chapter III and Chapter VIII of the Abolition Act are repugnant to the Constitution (Arts. 14, 19, 31).

petitioner_arguments.text: Abolition Act entirely void as not passed by duly constituted legislature of new Himachal Pradesh.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act 32 of 1954; Government of Part C States Act 49 of 1951 s.14; Representation of the People Act 1951 s.74

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of Ch. III and Ch. VIII inconsistent with Arts. 14, 19, 31.

respondent_arguments.text: s.15(1) New State Act deemed 36 old members elected to new Assembly; 5 vacancies do not vitiate under s.15(3) Part C States Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: New State Act s.15; Part C States Act s.15(3); Representation of People Act s.147(2); States Reorganisation Act s.25

respondent_arguments.text: Absence of fresh oath is mere irregularity cured by s.35 Part C States Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Part C States Act s.35; corresponding to Constitution Arts. 100(2), 189(2)

court_reasoning.text: New State Act created entirely new Himachal Pradesh; old State and Assembly ceased to exist.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Old HP and Bilaspur ceased; new State with 41-member Assembly required.

court_reasoning.text: s.15(1) New State Act deems 36 members elected but does not constitute Assembly; requires notification under s.74 ROP Act, oath under s.14 Part C Act, Speaker election.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deeming provision obviates election but post-election formalities mandatory.

court_reasoning.text: Notification summoned 'second session' indicating old Assembly; no fresh oath, no new Speaker elected; Jaiwant Ram continued as old Speaker.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Lieutenant Governor summoned old Assembly, not new one.

court_reasoning.text: s.15(3) Part C Act cures irregularities in existing Assembly, not absence of constitution.

holdings.text: Abolition Act not passed by duly constituted Legislative Assembly of new Himachal Pradesh; impugned Act not validly enacted.

statutes_cited.name: Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953 (Himachal 15 of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged as unconstitutional; provisions vest lands in tenants/State with compensation

statutes_cited.name: Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act, 1954 (32 of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Created new Himachal Pradesh; deemed old members elected but court held Assembly not constituted

statutes_cited.name: Government of Part C States Act, 1951 (49 of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governed old HP Assembly; s.15(3) and s.35 do not cure lack of constitution

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights enforcement; comparison for oaths/irregularities

outcome.summary: Petitions allowed on first ground; Abolition Act held void as not passed by duly constituted legislature of new Himachal Pradesh; no need to examine second ground; interference with petitioners' property rights not justified.
outcome.relief_granted: Enforcement of fundamental rights to property; Act declared invalid

key_quotes.text: the impugned Act cannot be regarded as a piece of validity enacted legislation.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The so called Legislative Assembly which was convened and which purported to pass the Abolition Act was not the Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh created by the New State Act
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: s.15(1) only provides that each of the 36 sitting members... shall be deemed to have been elected... The purpose of this section is to obviate the necessity for going through the entire process of a fresh election
key_quotes.speaker: court
